title: 108_hr5109
content: The "Airport Noise Curfew Act of 2004" establishes the "Airport Noise Curfew Commission" to study and recommend curfews on nonmilitary aircraft operations over populated areas during normal sleeping hours. The Airport Noise Curfew Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Speaker of the House, President pro tempore of the Senate, and heads of the EPA and FAA. Qualifications require industry representation and private citizens. The Chairperson is elected from private citizen members. The Airport Noise Curfew Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various officials, including industry representatives and private citizens. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members are entitled to receive pay based on the GS-18 grade of the General Schedule, with restrictions on additional compensation for federal employees. Members of the Airport Noise Curfew Commission are not eligible for extra pay, allowances, or benefits. They will receive travel expenses, including per diem, as per applicable regulations. SEC. 5. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Chairperson of the Commission may appoint staff and set their pay, without following certain civil service laws. The Chairperson can also hire experts and consultants as needed. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint staff and set their pay, and may hire experts and consultants as needed. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has the power to appoint staff, set their pay, hire experts, and consultants. Federal agencies can provide personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can obtain necessary information from federal departments and agencies and use the United States mails like other federal entities. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence within the United States to support its investigations under this Act. The Administrator of General Services can provide administrative support services to the Commission upon request. The Commission will submit a report to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment, and it will terminate upon transmitting the report.
